awd_titl_txt: Analytic Augmentation Component for Workshops on Computational Cybersecurity in Compromised Environments (C3E)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Computational Cybersecurity in Compromised Environments (C3E) workshop series identifies recent challenges in the changing cybersecurity landscape and explores different possible courses of research action. The workshops stimulate discussion and awareness among industry, academia and government that cybersecurity challenges are complex problems with many perspectives, competing interests, and possible consequences for society. The C3E workshops also offer challenge problems, encouraging team-oriented multidisciplinary approaches to investigate a challenge by considering socio-economic outcomes, trust, public safety, privacy risks, technology policy, and the larger consequences for society. 

The research theme for the upcoming C3E challenge problem is motivated by concerns over social-cyber manipulation at scale.  The challenge is to explore hybrid approaches to support cognitive security in human-machine teaming, leveraging advances in artificial intelligence, machine learning, and analytics at Internet scale. Of particular interest are processes for decision-making and analytic judgments that may be vulnerable to incorrect, incomplete, misleading, or misinformation in cyber-mediated contexts, the means to mitigate these vulnerabilities, and methods for restoring trust once lost. The research results will be widely disseminated to inform the research community and the general public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Analytic Augmentation Component for Workshops on Computational Cybersecurty in a Compromised Environment (C3) 


The Computational Cybersecurity in Compromised Environments (C3E) workshop series identifies recent challenges in the changing cybersecurity landscape and explores different possible courses of research action. The workshops stimulate discussion and awareness among industry, academia and government that cybersecurity challenges are complex problems with many perspectives, competing interests, and possible consequences for society. The C3E workshops also offer challenge problems, encouraging team-oriented multidisciplinary approaches to investigate a challenge by considering socio-economic outcomes, trust, public safety, privacy risks, technology policy, and the larger consequences for society.

Since 2013 each Workshop (C3E) has introduced Challenge Problems (CP) to provide an analytic augmentation to advance ideas developed at the Workshop. During the period of this grant, the themes of the C3E presented multiple options each year for the annual CP. These themes included: (1) economics of security; (2) continuous assurance; (3) supply chain software; (4) static analysis coverage analysis; (5) artificial intelligence applied to cybersecurity for the supply chain; and (6) computational victimology to develop risk models for supply chain cybersecurity. Researchers provided models, actual software applications (APPs) for open source use, narratives to define improvement to current processes, and tools or techniques for operational assessments and risk analysis. 

Researchers were required to prepare a five to ten-minute video describing their 9 to 12 month research efforts to present at the C3E workshops, a poster that describes their work, and a technical article suitable for publication in a major academic, professional publication. The outcomes included a description of the critical security events taking place and the research process followed for the effort, including details on how the research was conducted and possible issues or limitations associated with the results. Researchers were also given the opportunity to suggest follow-on activities.


Outcomes were disseminated to various government research organizations for possible follow-on efforts in addition to academic and commercial entities. Since many of the projects explored state-of-the-art concepts, researchers were encouraged to explore tech transfer opportunities. In addition to the C3E Workshop, researchers were also given the opportunity to brief their work at other government sponsored forums. Sixteen individual researchers and two teams participated in this research activity supporting the analytic component of the C3E Workshops.  


Last Modified: 01/30/2024
Modified by: Daniel G Wolf
